S2095-4956(23)00453-9 10.1016/j.jechem.2023.07.044 Science Press Fig. 1 A visual graph based on the data obtained from the Web of Science (duration 2017–2023.7) by using the keywords MXene and MOF as well as Metal-organic framework/MXene for electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Fig. 2 Typical elements used in MOFs and MXenes. The elements of the periodic table highlighted in violet and blue are used in the MOF phases and MXene phases, respectively. Various MOF/MXene systems featuring MOFs with different morphologies and dimensions inserted into MXene nanoarchitectures; are also shown. Graphical abstract Recent advances in MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures, tailoring their properties based on the morphologies (0D, 1D, and 2D), and broadening their future opportunities in electrochemical energy storage (batteries, supercapacitors) and catalytic energy conversion (HER, OER, and ORR). The development of urbanization and industrialization leads to rapid depletion of fossil fuels. Therefore, the production of fuel from renewable resources is highly desired. Electrotechnical energy conversion and storage is a benign technique with reliable output and is eco-friendly. Developing an exceptional electrochemical catalyst with tunable properties like a huge specific surface area, porous channels, and abundant active sites is critical points. Recently, Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and two-dimensional (2D) transition-metal carbides/nitrides (MXenes) have been extensively investigated in the field of electrochemical energy conversion and storage. However, advances in the research on MOFs are hampered by their limited structural stability and conventionally low electrical conductivity, whereas the practical electrochemical performance of MXenes is impeded by their low porosity, inadequate redox sites, and agglomeration. Consequently, researchers have been designing MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures to overcome the limitations in electrochemical energy conversion and storage. This review explores the recent advances in MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures design strategies, tailoring their properties based on the morphologies (0D, 1D, 2D, and 3D), and broadening their future opportunities in electrochemical energy storage (batteries, supercapacitors) and catalytic energy conversion (HER, OER, and ORR). The intercalation of MOF in between the MXene layers in the nanoarchitectures functions synergistically to address the issues associated with bare MXene and MOF in the electrochemical energy storage and conversion. This review gives a clear emphasis on the general aspects of MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures, and the future research perspectives, challenges of MOF/MXene design strategies and electrochemical applications are highlighted. Keywords Metal-organic framework MXene MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture Battery Supercapacitor Electrochemical catalysis 1 Introduction 1.1 Importance of electrochemical energy and limitations The rapid growth in industrial, transportation, and e-technology sectors has accelerated energy consumption, causing fossil fuel depletion, global warming, and environmental pollution; this has escalated the demand for cost-effective, advanced, and versatile electrochemical-storage-and-conversion technologies (batteries, supercapacitors, fuel cells, and H2 production) [1,2]. Therefore, advanced, adaptable, and cost-effective electrochemical-energy-storage systems are in great demand [3,4]. There are numerous materials that have been reported such as transitional metal chalcogenides, metal oxide nanoparticles, conductive polymers, layered double hydroxide materials (LDH), graphene, and other nanocarbon materials, etc., [5–15]. Nevertheless, transition metal chalcogenides upon charging and discharging suffer from significant volume variation, which results in low intrinsic electrical conductivity, rapid capacity fading, and cause inferior rate capability [16–18]. In the case of electrochemical capacitors, the metal oxide nanoparticles will suffer huge agglomeration, low specific surface area, and mesoporous channels, resulting in low energy density, slow ion diffusion in the bulk phase, and poor mechanical stability thwarting their industrial applications [19,20]. In addition, layered double hydroxide materials with feasible properties like morphology, tenability, 2D structures, and 3D hierarchical porous features facilitate good catalyst and electrode materials for supercapacitors with high theoretical capacity. Nevertheless, during the charging and discharging process, the structure undergoes agglomeration, a fragile character, which possesses poor cycling stability and reduces the reversible capacity [21]. In another case, considering that nanocarbon materials such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, and activated porous carbon have a high specific surface area, high electrical conductivity, thermal/electrochemical stability, and porous channels make deliberate nanocarbon materials for electrochemical applications. Although some shortages of nanocarbon materials like strong π-π interactions lead to agglomeration, which results in reducing the actual capacitance of graphene than the theoretical value [22,23]. In another scenario, conductive polymers are widely used in energy storage and conversion applications because of their light weight, flexibility, and excellent electrochemical properties [24]. Nevertheless, pristine conductive polymers suffer poor electron transfer efficiency, slow kinetics, and poor conductivity [25]. Considering the current global situation and the increasing demand for hybrid electronic vehicles, the electrochemical energy storage and conversion market is expected to continue expanding in the future. Moreover, nanostructured composite materials play a pivotal role in the electrochemical energy sector. Therefore, designing economically viable nanoarchitecture catalysts is of utmost importance in electrochemical energy. 1.2 Scope of the review In particular, MOFs and MXenes (2D transition-metal carbides/nitrides) have drawn attention as optimal materials in the field of energy storage and conversion [26,27]. The present review focuses particularly in the recent advancement of MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture in the field of electrochemical energy storage and conversion as a newborn material with their advancements, limitations, and future scope of the nanoarchitecture design. Until now there are only a few reviews reported on the MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture and their versatile applications and solar energy applications [28,29]. Moreover, very recently Yang et al. [30] reported a review of the MOF/MXene for electrochemical applications. However, there is still room for a deep understating of why MOF/MXene is superior for electrochemical chemical energy conversion and storage. Considering the wide audience and the emerging field of electrochemical energy, this review highlighted the designing of MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture and their applications in the field of electrochemical energy storage and conversion (batteries, supercapacitors, fuel cells, oxygen evolution reaction, and hydrogen evolution reaction) in-depth discussion. We have given a visual graph (Fig. 1 ), based on the literature there is a huge future opportunity for the development of MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures as a catalyst for energy storage and conversion. 1.3 Critical advantages and limitations of metal–organic frameworks and MXenes MOFs have flourished as traditional porous materials since their invention by Yaghi et al. in the late 1990 s [31,32], with thousands of MOF structures (>90,000) developed over the last two decades [33]. Despite their large void volume, which has been attributed to their high porosity—MOFs have extended, rigid crystalline structures where metal-ion nodes are coordinatively cross-connected with various functional organic linkers (Fig. 2 ). The key structural features of MOFs include significantly high internal surface area (1000–10,000 m2 g−1), exceptional porosity, high crystallinity, and functional tunability. These attributes are crucial for applications such as gas sensors and energy storage/conversion [34–37]. Slightly tuning any structural parameter can yield completely different MOFs with modified physicochemical characteristics [38–40]. The heat treatment process of MOF can give various derivatives like meal clusters/oxides, stable carbon matric hybrids, and hetero atom coordinated single atom moieties, which will give unique properties compared to their bare MOF structure. For example, Zhou et al. synthesized Co/Co@NSC catalyst derived from Zn-MOF/Co-MOF, owing to high porosity and intact metal@carbon structure of MOF derived Co/Co@NSC catalyst enable excellent OER, ORR activity and aqueous zinc air battery applications [41]. ZIF-8 derived highly conductive carbon used as a capacitive type of anode material in sodium ion capacitors by Gu et al. group [42]. This MOF derived carbon shows a high surface area (1259 m2 g−1) compared to commercial activated carbon (898 m2 g−1), which provides more adsorption sites for ions and enhances the capacity. Whereas Zhou et al. developed a unique Co single atom coordinated with three nitrogen atoms and one carbon moiety (Co-N3C) derived from ZIF-L/ZIF-8 precursor, which gives high ORR and Zn air battery activity [43]. Therefore, MOF derivatives intercalation with MXene layers may create new room for electrochemical energy conversion and storage applications. MXenes are a new class of 2D multilayered inorganic materials that are derived from parent MAX-phase precursors through selective etching approaches also termed topochemical strategies [44–47]. MXenes are typically expressed as M( x +1)X n T x (for example, Ti3C2T x ), where M is a transition metal (such as Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Hf, Mo, and Ta), X denotes C or N, and T represents the surface terminating groups (such as O, OH, or F; Fig. 2) [44,48,49]. MXene nanoparticles have attracted attention in research for energy storage and conversion due to their exceptional physicochemical properties, such as their 2D lamellar structures, formation of 3D aerogel, high electrical and thermal conductivities, hydrophilicity, and adjustable interlayer spacing [50–55]. Although MOFs have significant advantages, their inadequate chemical/thermal stability, poor electrical conductivity, and structural porosity result in low coulombic efficiency, inferior mechanical resistance, and fragility, inhibiting their direct use as electrode and catalytic materials [56]. Similarly, MXenes have not achieved widespread industrial applications in terms of energy storage devices (such as batteries and supercapacitors [SCs]) and in conversion reactions (such as hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR)), despite their advantages. This is due to their low porosity, low gravimetric efficiency, agglomeration, dearth of active sites, and ability to hinder ion transformation, in addition to the self-rehabilitation of MXene nanosheets [57]. 1.4 Significance of designing MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures The limitations of MOFs and MXenes have inspired the development of distinct hybrid structures, including MOF-based composites like MOF/reduced graphene oxide, MOF/carbon nanotubes, MOF-on-MOF systems, MOF/metal-oxide nanoparticles, and MXene/rGO, etc., [58–62]. Fig. 3 provides the timeline of the individual MOF, MXene composites, and MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures; for energy storage and conversion [63–95]. However, these individual MOF and MXene composites have agglomeration- and restacking-related issues, which diminish their active metal sites and electrochemical energy storage, and conversion capacity [96,97]. Importantly, the formation of multidimensional structures using these composites is challenging. Therefore, MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures are in the limelight for the following reasons (Fig. 4 ). (1) The insertion of a porous MOF between 2D MXenes can yield porous high-surface-area nanoarchitectures [98]. (2) The components of the nanoarchitectures synergistically inhibit the agglomeration and restacking of the MXene interlayers, thereby accelerating ion/electron transport [99]. (3) The interlayer voids can increase the number of active sites exposed by subtle branches, enabling them to store considerable amounts of electrochemical energy [100]. (4) The synthesized hybrid materials are flexible, and the electrode stress generated during charging and discharging can be reduced [101]. (5) MOF-derived porous metal oxides enclosed by MXene layers exhibit enhanced chemical and mechanical stability [102]. (6) Nanoarchitectures with high packing density are particularly suitable for electrochemical-energy-storage devices [103–107]. As we know MXenes were available in various transition metal combinations such as Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Hf, Mo. However, based on the literature availability we comprehensively reviewed titanium and vanadium based MXene/MOF nanoarchitectures from the viewpoint of energy storage and conversion. 2 Chemistry behind on MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures design strategies The dimensions of the MOF and MXene are considered vital in designing MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures, particularly because MOFs exhibit two forms: their original phases and those derived porous transition-metal/metal-oxide derivatives. The rigidity and flexibility of MOFs can enable outstanding properties through adjustment of their porosity, size, morphology, and functionality [108]. Additionally, MXenes can readily react with various molecules or structures due to the abundance of negatively charged termination functional groups on their surface and have high d-space in between the layers [109]. Pristine MOFs and MXenes are synthesized using contrasting methodologies, with the former typically produced using bottom-up strategies based on the self-assembly of metal ions and coordinating ligands, and the latter mainly prepared using top-down methods [100–112]. Several approaches have been adopted to synthesize MXenes, with the strategy selected based on the intercalated anions and the cations that form the hydroxide layers. Typically, MXenes exhibit crystallinity, phase purity, and conductivity. During hybridization, MXenes can easily react with guest molecules or metal ions due to the covalent bonding, interlayer hydrogen bonding, van der Waals, and electrostatic interactions. The MXene layer offers an open channel between the layers, increasing the d-spacing of MXenes and facilitating as a host for guest molecules. However, MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures are synthesized primarily using wet-chemical strategies, such as interdiffusion-assisted hybridization, hydrothermal methods, ultrasonication, coprecipitation, ion-conversion exchange, liquid exfoliation followed by dry-chemical processing (i.e., pyrolysis), and carbothermal reduction [28]. In particular, the negative charge on the MXene surface (–(F), –(OH)) aids in electrostatically absorbing the metal ions and subsequently coordinates with the organic linkers, promoting in-situ growth of MOFs in the intercalated MXene layers. Notably, MOFs can also be used as spacers, which expands the interplanar gap by disrupting the electrostatic repulsion between the MXene layers, thereby imparting active sites, ion transport, and storage capacity to the MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture. 2.1 Original phases of MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures with intact original phases have recently been synthesized. The in-situ strategy is the most promising technique for the synthesis of nanoarchitecture materials. Most of the MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures were designed by in situ strategy because of the abundant availability of surface functional and d spacing of MXene layers. The negatively charged functional groups act as a host via electrostatic attraction of the cations, which further coordinated with the targeted organic linkers and grew the MOF moiety throughout the MXene surface as well as between the layers. In this strategy, the agglomeration of the MXene layer is negligible because in situ growth of MOF can provide more space in the nanoarchitecture and elevate more active sites, enhancing the conductivity of the catalyst. The in-situ is a generic method for the design of MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture by retaining their original phases of MOF and MXene, for example, solvothermal (hydrothermal), interdiffusion reaction strategy and ultrasonication, etc. 2.1.1 Solvothermal (hydrothermal) method A hydrothermal method is a simple and convenient technique to produce a large quantity of composite materials by tuning the temperature and pressure from low to high. The principle of the hydrothermal method is nucleation, and the growth of nanoparticles occurs in the presence of a high-pressure chamber (auto-clave) at a desired temperature. Most importantly, the loss of materials is low, can use a wide range of solvents, and can design nanoparticles, nanorods, nanosheets, hollow structures, etc. Several MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures were reported by the hydrothermal method as follows: The MIL-88B-Fe/Ti3C2 hybrid nanoarchitecture was synthesized by hydrothermal followed by heating [113]. Remarkably, the MIL-88B-Fe framework did not collapse, and the framework structure was preserved with the MXene. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) revealed a thermal activation temperature of 200–250 °C, confirming the structural stability of the MOF at temperatures below 250 °C. Similarly, a Fe-MIL-100/Ti3C2 nanoarchitecture was fabricated by Wang et al. [114] by enabling gradual growth of Fe-MIL-100 on the surface of Ti3C2 layers and establishing strong links based on the abundant negatively charged surface terminal groups of Ti3C2. Fe-MIL-100 enhanced the lattice spacing and pore size of the architecture, which was anticipated to enhance the photocatalytic nitrogen fixation activity. Additionally, a novel hybrid HKUST-1/Ti3C2T x architecture was designed to enhance the hydrothermal stability of pristine HKUST-1 [115] by incorporating a 2D layered MXene; the resulting HKUST-1/Ti3C2T x architecture exhibited a large surface area and symmetric porosity, which could be leveraged for energy-related applications. A UIO-66-NH2/TiO2/Ti3C2 hybrid structure was synthesized using a simple one-pot hydrothermal method [116]. Briefly, MXene powder was annealed under N2 to produce TiO2 layers, and the MOF was synthesized thereafter by adding the obtained TiO2-layer-containing Ti3C2 (MXene) to a solution of ZrCl4 and BDC-NH2 (2-amino terephthalic acid). The hybrid UIO-66-NH2/TiO2/Ti3C2 structure was obtained after solvothermal treatment at 120 °C for 24 h. A ZIF-67/Ti3C2 hybrid was prepared by Liang et al. via ultrasonication (liquid exfoliation) [117]. The MOF was synthesized in situ on the MXene surface, which altered the electrophilicity of the active centers of the ZIF-67/Ti3C2 hybrid, underscoring its durability for catalysis. The synthesis strategies can enable the production of MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures with intact original phases, more active-edge functional groups (such as O, N, and F), and high porosity, resulting in excellent catalytic energy conversion and storage. 2.1.2 Interdiffusion reaction strategy Designing hetero nanostructures by interdiffusion reaction was widely employed, which is a surfactant free easy method. The 2D MOF+2D MXene (Co-BDC/Ti3C2T x ) to 2D nanoarchitecture via interdiffusion reaction assisted strategy was used by Zhao and coworkers. This method was carried out in a simple test tube by using N,N dimethylformamide/acetonitrile (DMF/CH3CN) solvent medium different volume ratio with the three-layer process. The Co2+ ions and 2D Ti3C2T x sheets are present in the top layer solution, whereas 1,4 benzene dicarboxylate (1,4-BDC) ligand was dissolved in the bottom layer of the solution. As discussed, early MXene sheets have functional groups (OH, F, etc.), which will drag the Co2+ ions via electrostatic interaction after that due to the gravity the Co2+ ions anchored sheets are moved to the middle layer and coordinate with the 1,4-BDC ligand and diffused into the bottom to the middle layer, the hybrid structure material was settled into the bottom. Finally, the synthesized Co-BDC/Ti3C2T x hybrid material was treated thermally at 400 °C under an inert atmosphere [89]. 2.1.3 Sonochemical synthesis Chemical reactions (breaking or formation) occur by passing the ultrasonic waves in the liquid phase. Ultrasonication is a powerful technique to accelerate the formation of MXene 2D sheets from the parent MAX phase by delaminating, and exfoliating following the principle of acoustic cavitation in the solvent. Liang and coworkers synthesized ZIF-67/Ti3C2 hybrid by ultrasonication (liquid exfoliation) method followed by stirring [117]. They highlighted the in-situ growth of MOF on the surface of MXene leads to a change in the electrophilicity of the active center of the ZIF-67/Ti3C2 hybrid and illustrates durability in the catalysis process. The above synthesis strategies give a patch for the production of MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures without the collapse of their original framework phases and increase the active edge functional groups (O, N, F, etc.), offer huge porosity with surface area, which will endow excellent catalytic conversion of energy and energy storage. 2.2 MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures obtained from porous-metal-oxide derivatives of MOFs Pyrolysis (carbothermal) method Pyrolysis is a heat treatment technique to break the organic molecules into a highly porous conductive support carbon moiety in the presence of an inert or reductive atmosphere. For example, MOFs are a combination of metal nodes and organic moieties. After pyrolysis, MOFs can generate effective metal/metal oxide nanoparticle active sites that are intercalated with a porous carbon shell (defective or non-defective). These MOFs derived nanoparticles can easily be introduced into the MXene layers via ultrasonication, electrostatic self-assembly, and hydrothermal and pyrolysis methods (Fig. 5 ). The strong covalent interaction between MXene functional groups and metal nodes derived from MOF leads to an excellent MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture with multiple active sites and porous channels, which reduces the agglomeration of the nanoarchitecture and enhances the activity towards electrochemical applications. Very recently, Ye and coworkers reported 0D MOF+2D MXene to 0D-2D hierarchical porous (CoZn-Se@N-MX) nanoarchitecture by self-assembly of bimetallic MOFs on nitrogen doped 2D MXenes followed by an in-situ gas phase selenization strategy at 800 °C. In addition, this group also applied the metal diffusion method for S doping into the developed CoZn-Se@N-MX nanoarchitecture under an Ar atmosphere at 155 °C, 12 h. Further, a conversion of 0D MOF+2D MXene to 2D nanoarchitecture (Ni@C-MXene) was reported by Huang and coworkers [48]. The Ni-MOF was carbonization at 700 °C where the MOF frame was collapsed and derived spherical 0D Ni@C nanoparticles, which were further treated with 2D MXene via ultrasonication to attain Ni@C-MXene heterostructure. MOF/MXene hybrid nanoarchitectures of varying dimensions can be effectively applied in the fields of catalysis and energy conversion/storage. To that end, controlling the dimensionality of the nanostructures generated using MOFs and MXenes as building blocks is vital. Hybrid nanostructures of varying dimensions have been prepared by tailoring the morphology of pristine MOFs and MXenes via manipulation of synthesis parameters like temperature, time concentration, medium, and substrate [101,118]. In this section, the synthesis strategies are categorized based on the morphology and dimensionalities of the MOF and MXene building blocks, and the resulting hybrid nanostructures are highlighted in Table S1. 3 Aspects of MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures that favor energy storage and conversion To realize a global economy free of fossil fuel utilization and greenhouse gas emissions, studies on establishing foundational concepts are being conducted for developing advanced energy-storage-and-conversion devices, such as batteries and supercapacitors (SCs) [95,119–125]. MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures have recently been reviewed by Saini et al. with a focus on their design and versatile applications [28]. However, the crucial parameters and performance of state-of-the-art MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures, particularly for electrochemical energy, were not scrutinized. Therefore, the potential electrochemical-energy-related advantages of MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures are discussed herein (Fig. 6 ). 3.1 Hierarchical porosity and large surface area MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures with a hierarchical porosity and large surface area exhibit enhanced ion-insertion capability and facilitated energy storage [126]. Additionally, they can readily overcome issues such as dendrite formation, shutting effect, and volume expansion. The hierarchical porous structure of MOF/MXene systems can trap dendrites and shuttling species and make them immobile, thereby facilitating uninterrupted ion/electron transport. The presence of the MOF on the top and between the MXene interlayers results in numerous symmetric pores, which act as a volume buffer and make the device resistant to volume expansion. Furthermore, the surface of MOF/MXene systems can reduce contact between the electrolyte and electrode interface and decrease the device resistance. Moreover, large surface areas facilitate catalytic processes such as the ORR. 3.2 Structural defects, active sites Structural defects and active sites are regions that exhibit activity for certain reactions. Both MOFs and MXenes have structural defects and abundant active sites [127,128]. In general, MXenes are an imperfect crystalline structure having both native and extrinsic defects. The atomic defects on MXene can form at C, N, O site or metallic site. From the XPS it was confirmed that 10% of the carbon vacant defect of MXene is attributed to its parent MAX phase. On the contrary, scanning transmission electron microscopy reveals the presence of Ti vacancies in MXene [129]. Recently, Jiang et al. designed a Fenton like catalyst using an MXene template by tuning the surface defects into catalytic active sites. Lattice distortion defects were identified by HRTEM, and positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy (PALS) reveals two positron lifetime components, which ascribed the MXene bulk defects and also outer or inner layer defects [130]. An interesting point is that MXene surface functional groups interact with defects, which can tailor the structural properties of MXene and provide an additional benefit [131]. Similarly, the intrinsic point defects in MXene layers can modulate properties such as conductivity, capacitance, and proton transfer, thereby facilitating electrochemical reactions. MOFs are crystalline porous materials having various types of defects in their structure. There are four types of defects (i) point defects, (ii) line defects, (iii) micro and mesoscale volume defects, and (iv) planar defects. Based on the synthesis reaction conditions (e.g., temperature or concentration) these defects formation occurs [132]. MOFs with point defects primarily missing linkers from pristine framework structure and cluster defects [133–135]. For example, Zhao et al. initiated missing linkers to a 2D CoBDC to tune its structure, which leads to highly active OER activity, and theoretical insights reveal that new CoBDC-Fc formed due to replace of terephthalic acid in CoBDC by carboxy ferrocene (Fc), which enhance the electrical conductivity of the CoBDC-Fc catalyst [89]. Defect engineering is vital for modifying the surface and structural features of MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures, and potentially influencing the factionalized active sites during electrochemical reactions, thereby enhancing the conductivity and capacity of the electrode material. Therefore, MXene templates with few defects and active sites intercalating with MOFs can have abundant active sites, particularly at the atomic level, thereby triggering electrochemical catalytic activity [118]. 3.3 Stability and scalability MOFs with electrochemical stability can be realized by selecting appropriate synthesis parameters. For instance, MOFs comprising redox-inactive sites with shorter and rigid linkers have been found to exhibit greater electrochemical stability. Under ambient conditions, adequate control of surface terminations is crucial to ensuring the stability of MXenes, whereas, at high temperatures, MXenes can easily be oxidized even in the absence of oxidizing agents owing to their surface termination groups. Additionally, interfacial interactions must be controlled to realize stable MOF/MXene nanostructures. The scalability of MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures is crucial for commercializing laboratory-derived materials. MXenes are typically synthesized using mechanochemical methods followed by chemical etching, which are cost-effective approaches that do not sacrifice purity. The intercalation of non-noble-metal MOFs, which are stable and easy to synthesize, with MXene templates can provide economic benefits and enhance the large-scale-production potential of MOF/MXene nanostructures. The development of economically viable battery systems with a long cycle life and high power/energy densities using novel electrode materials with nanoarchitectures is critical [128,129]. Currently, MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures have considerable potential in battery, SC, and catalytic applications owing to their excellent characteristics, such as high porosity, large surface area, numerous active edges, robust electrical conductivity, chemical/thermal stability, and tunable redox channels. However, few noteworthy MOF/MXene hybrid nanoarchitectures have been reported as active materials for energy storage. For instance, the CoSe2@MXene-based lithium-ion-battery (LIB) anode performed adequately with outstanding properties, because the hollow nanoarchitectures prevented the restacking of the 2D nanosheets, enhancing the number of open channels, forming numerous cavities for rapid electrochemical ion transport (Fig. 7 ). Moreover, the 2D MXenes provided excellent conductivity, and the MOFs derived metal-oxide nanosheets exhibited impressive Li-storage capacities. Consequently, excellent reversible capacities, outstanding rate behavior, and remarkably high stability were achieved [136]. The following section describes recent advances in MOF/MXene architectures for energy storage applications. 4 Electrochemical energy storage and conversion applications 4.1 Recent advances in MOF/MXene architectures for energy storage applications Continuous worries about the rapid use of fossil fuels, global warming, environmental pollution, and an ever-growing fleet of cars have significantly sped up the development of enhanced energy systems such as batteries and supercapacitors that outperform currently existing electrochemical storage devices [113–115]. The 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to scientists who developed LIBs, which have potential as they offer green alternatives to fossil fuel technologies, helping to reduce CO2 and other greenhouse gases [116,117]. Moreover, Li–S batteries, Na-ion batteries (SIBs), and K-ion batteries (PIBs) have been developed for use in high-energy-storage, green, and low-cost systems [89,118]. The critical elements of advanced energy storage systems, however, are materials science aspects that implement novel, unique materials science concepts, such as cutting-edge electrodes and electrolytes, and advanced methodologies to describe the key differentiating characteristics that regulate the behavior of advanced electrochemical storage systems [137,138]. Therefore, outstanding MOF/MXene hybrid nanoarchitectures that are employed as energy-storing electrode materials are highlighted herein. Currently, MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures have considerable potential in battery applications owing to their excellent properties, such as high porosity, numerous active edges, and chemical/thermal stability. 4.1.1 Batteries 4.1.1.1 Li-ion batteries A 3D ultralight porous MOF@MXene aerogel ((CoS NP@NHC)@MXene; Fig. 8 ) has been reported as an outstanding electrode material for energy storage [139]. This 3D nanoarchitecture facilitated the operation of three types of conjugative alkali-ion batteries: LIBs, SIBs, and PIBs. The MOFs derived CoS, C layers, and MXenes exhibited strong coupling interfaces in the hierarchical porous 3D nanoarchitecture networks, which increased their electrochemical conductivity and prevented volume changes, resulting in notable ion diffusion; enhanced reactivity of the LIBs, SIBs, and PIBs; high rates; excellent capacities; and stable cycling behavior. The LIBs, SIBs, and PIBs retained specific capacities of 1146, 420, and 200 mA h g−1 at 1, 2, and 2Ag−1 after 800, 650, and 500 cycles, respectively. Comprehensively, the electrochemical performance of (CoS NP@NHC)@MXene nanoarchitecture elucidated its suitability for metal-ion batteries. Three-dimensional porous Ti3C2/NiCo-MOF composites were obtained by Liu et al., via interlayer hydrogen bonding between Ti3C2 and NiCo-MOF nanosheets and then utilized as a LIB anode [92]. The stratiform-like structure of the alternating Ti3C2 and composite films was believed to play a major role in enhancing the surface area and extending the interlayer spacing, which permitted facile Li-ion percolation into the electrode. Consequently, the Ti3C2/NiCo-MOF architecture delivered a high reversible capacity (402 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles at a current density of 0.1 A g−1) and decent rate performance (256 mA h g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1). The designed MXene/MOF architecture retained 85.7% of its capacity even after 400 cycles and exhibited a dominant diffusion-controlled energy storage mechanism. To develop the stable anodes for Li-ion storage, Sun et al., designed a Ni-ferrocene based MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture (NF-MOF/MXene) by an in-situ solvothermal method in Fig. 9 . This hybrid structure exhibited remarkable improvements in Li+ storage capabilities, surpassing the individual components. The integration of Ti3C2T x with the NF-MOF resulted in significant charge redistribution from MXene to MOF and enhanced Li + adsorption energy [140]. The heterostructure demonstrated superior performance in terms of capacity (620 at 1 A g−1), rate performance, and cycling stability (up to 5000 cycles with 80% capacity retention), outperforming the individual MXene and MOF materials. Furthermore, when applied as an anode in a LIB alongside a commercial cathode, the heterostructure achieved high energy and power densities. These findings offer valuable insights for the development of advanced electrode materials in energy storage applications. Similarly, Liu et al. developed CoP-NC@MXene with a sandwich-like structure by subjecting ZIF-67/Ti3C2T x derivatives to phosphorylation (Fig. 10 a–g) [100]. The resulting CoP-NC provided active sites and helped expand the interlayer spacing between the MXene layers, further promoting the Li/Na-ion. storage capacity (Fig. 10h). As LIB and SIB anode, the CoP-NC@MXene system delivered capacities of 147.8 and 101.6 mA h g−1 after 2000 and 500 repeated cycles at 1 and 0.5 A g−1, respectively. Later on, ZnS nanodots were synthesized on Ti3C2T x nanosheets by Cao et al. using a unique approach [141], with the 0D ZnS nanodots derived from sulfurized ZIF-8. This 0D/2D combination exhibited strong interfacial interactions, which immobilized the ZnS dots on the MXene surface through interfacial Ti–O–Zn bonds (Fig. 11 ); moreover, the prepared composite was remarkably resilient to volume fluctuations and achieved consistent electron conduction and lithium diffusion. The ZnS-Ti3C2T x architecture exhibited remarkable Li-storage capability (462.8 mA h g−1) with exceptionalcycle longevity (1000 cycles at 0.5 A g−1)and rate capability (252.5 mA h g−1 at a current density of 2.0 A g−1); these were mostly attributed to the pseudocapacitive/surface-dominating Li-storage performance with robust electrochemical dynamics. The high Li-adsorption capacity improved interfacial electron transport, and the lower ion-diffusion barrier of the ZnS-Ti3C2T x interface was further clarified by DFT simulations. The aforementioned approach was noted to be feasible for other metal dichalcogenides in terms of electrochemical-energy-storage applications(see Fig. 11 for structural feasibility of the interfacial interactions at the ZnS–Ti3C2T x interface, which enhanced the electron/Li-ion transport). A dual-confinement technique was adopted by Zhang et al. to incorporate Si nanoparticles into an MXene/ZIF-8-derived carbon framework for enhancing the Li-storing capability of the battery [142]. Owing to coordinating bonds such as Si–O–Ti and Si–C, the Si nanoparticles established strong links with the surfaces of the MXene and MOF-derived carbon in the Si/MXene@C composite, which helped alleviate the volume expansion and enabled electron transfer at the MXene–MOF interface. The Si/MXene@C composite exhibited the following structural benefits: (1) The Ti3C2T x substrate and MOF-derived carbon layer simultaneously constructed a porous, conductive architecture that was vital for enhancing interfacial electron transmission. (2) Si/MXene@C was endowed with a porous nanoarchitecture owing to the 2D MXene substrate, which enhanced the accessibility of the electrolyte to surface-active sites and reduced the large volume fluctuations of Si due to Li intercalation. (3) The strong coordination bonds of Si with the MXene and MOF-derived carbon (Si–O–Ti and Si–C) prevented Si-particle agglomeration and reduced Si-related volume fluctuations. Practically, the Si/MXene@C-based anode exhibited a high capacity (1006.1 mA h g−1 at a current density of 100 mA g−1), steady cycling performance (862.9 mA h g−1 for 150 cycles at a current density of 100 mA g−1), and excellent rate capability at 5 A g−1 with 233.3 mA h g−1 capacity, validating the Li-storing capability of the Si/MXene@C composite for high-performance LIBs [142]. Octahedral VSe2-ZrO2/C/MXene composite particles were recently synthesized using a two-step process (Fig. 12 a–e) [143]. In the resulting novel structure, the V2CT x -derived VSe2/MXene helped realize a high reversible capacity, the VSe2 uniformly anchored on the carbon with the assistance of ZrO2 improved the electrochemical stability, and the MOF-derived porous carbon buffered the volumetric fluctuations and then promoted Li-ion transportation (Fig. 12f). Consequently, VSe2-ZrO2/C/MXene exhibited an outstanding reversible capacity and longevity, with a gravimetric capacity of 430 mA h g−1 after 1000 reaerated cycles at a current density of 1 A g−1. 4.1.1.2 Li-S batteries Li–S batteries are conventional electrochemical batteries with significantly higher theoretical energy density (2600 W h kg−1) than other metal-ion batteries [144,145]. However, the practical applications of Li–S batteries are hindered owing to several limitations, particularly polysulfide shuttling, which weakens the electrolytic effect during charging and discharging by consuming S ions [146]. Zero-dimensional to two-dimensional (0D–2D) hierarchical MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures (CoZnSe@N–MX) which exhibited 10-fold-higher surface areas than that of the pure MXene—have recently been developed to address these limitations [71,126]. Interestingly, the nanoarchitectures had combinations of micro, meso, and macroporous active phases, which offered the following significant advantages: (i) The microporous phase enabled sufficient wetting of the catalytically active sites, as the efficient confinement of the electrolyte favored the kinetics of solid-liquid polysulfide transformation. (ii) The volume variation of Li2S2/Li2S during continuous lithiation was effectively curtailed by the interior mesoporous phase. (iii) The large pore volume of the microporous phase provided abundant space for considerable S loading within the CoZnSe@N-MX nanoarchitectures. Additionally, density functional theory (DFT) calculations suggested that the energy barrier for Li2S decomposition on the CoZnSe@N-MX nanoarchitectures (0.002 eV) was smaller than that on the pure MXene (0.12 eV). According to Ye et al., the strong covalent Ti–S bonds inhibited diffusion, and the electrochemical transformation of the lithium polysulfides weakened the shuttling effect. Therefore, the developed hierarchical porous nanoarchitectures enhanced the lifetime of the Li–S batteries, yielding rate capacities with ultralow decreases of 0.034% per cycle over 2000 cycles. Therefore, these nanoarchitectures have enormous potential as electrode materials for Li–S batteries. A facile, scalable approach involving electrostatic interactions and solvothermal methods has been employed to produce a 3D hierarchical nMOF-867/Ti3C2T x system (see Fig. 13 a for the synthesis strategy and operational mechanism of the Zr-MOF/Ti3C2T x composite) [92,147]. In the heterostructure, the highly porous nMOF-867 particles chemically captured the polysulfides via stable double bonds (Zr–S, and Li–N) originating from the Lewis acid-base reaction between the Li polysulfides and Zr-MOF (Fig. 13b). Furthermore, the nMOF-867 nanoparticle dispersion on the highly conductive MXene encouraged reverse redox transformation of the adsorbed polysulfides. Additionally, the volume fluctuations during lithiation/delithiation were mitigated owing to the excellent physical stability and porosity of nMOF-867/Ti3C2T x . Therefore, as the sulfur host of Li–S batteries, nMOF-867/Ti3C2T x exhibited outstanding rate capability (581 mA h g−1 at a current rate of 4 C) and an exceptional reversible capacity (1302 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C). Moreover, an impressive starting capacity (801 mA h g−1) was achieved at 1 C, and this value was maintained with a minimal capacity fading rate (0.054%) per cycle over 1000 cycles. Zong et al. reported a MOF-derived CoP/MXene nanoarchitecture for LIBs [103], in which ZIF-67 particles and MXene layers were self-assembled and transformed into CoP@MXene using a room-temperature in situ approach followed by phosphorization (Fig. 14 a). The CoP nanostructure was affixed to the MXene network. The MOFs-CoP@MXene system exhibited improved Li-storing capability owing to its unique dual functionalities (Fig. 14b, c). Furthermore, cobalt phosphide, a -byproduct of the MOFs exerted a catalytic influence on the tendency of Li+ to participate in electrochemical reactions in addition to having a distinctive 3D architecture and a high surface area. Additionally, the Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets which had 2D layers and abundant terminating functional groups played a major role in enhancing the pseudocapacitive properties. The CoP@MXene system exhibited improved life-span durability and reversible capacity when used as a LIB anode, yielding discharge capacities of 706.5 and 585.8 mA h g−1 after 200 and 1000 cycles at current densities of 0.2 and 0.5 A g−1, respectively. As a Li–S battery cathode, CoP@MXene exhibited steady electrochemical performance and efficiently mitigated shuttling, delivering a capacity of 796.9 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles at a current density of 0.2 C. Jiang et al. fabricated a noteworthy multifunctional separator comprising ZIF-67 derivatives on nitrogen-doped Ti3C2 (N-Ti3C2/C@PP) using an in situ approach with a polypropylene substrate for Li–S batteries (Fig. 15 ) [148]. The Ti3C2 surface was partially covered with ZIF-67-derived nanoparticles, ensuring the availability of abundant accessible Lewis-acidic active surface sites for chemical adsorption. Additionally, the coordination links between ZIF-67 and the Ti3C2 nanosheets were established owing to nitrogen, which increased the adsorption capability. Furthermore, N-Ti3C2/C@PP successfully mitigated polysulfide shuttling and dendrite growth in the anode (Fig. 15h). Consequently, the assembled Li–S batteries exhibited an excellent reversible gravimetric capacity (1332 mA h g−1 at a scan rate of 0.1C) and stable prolonged cycling (716 mA h g−1 at a scan rate of 0.5 C over 500 cycles). 4.1.1.3 Zn based batteries Recently, Wang et al. studied the incorporation of a 2D MOF (Cu-HHTP) into the layers of the V2CT x MXene through solution-phase MOF assembly in the presence of MXene sheets for Zn-ion batteries (ZIBs) [149]. The resulting Cu-HHTP/MX architecture had alternately stacked MOF sheets between MXene sheets, which improved the electron conduction as well as prevented the aggregation on nanosheets during repeated charging and discharging. Moreover, the Cu-HHTP layers functioned as the primary active layer for Zn2+ storage as well as a spacer for separating the MXene nanosheets, enabling rapid insertion and extraction of Zn2+, which amplified the specific capacity and rate performance. Additionally, the Cu-HHTP/MX heterostructure exhibited a capacity of 260.1 mA h g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and long-term cycling stability, with 92.5% capacity retention after 1000 repeated cycles. Similarly, Ni-NDC nanosheets have been encapsulated with Ti3C2 sheets and utilized in LIBs, which achieved a reversible specific capacity of 579.8 mA h g−1 at a current density of 100 mA g−1 over 100 cycles and decent long-term cycling performance (capacity of 310 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 A g−1) [150]. Zhao et al. designed a unique catalyst named 2D Ti3C2T x /Co–BDC nanoarchitecture and applied it as an electrocatalyst for OER and also as an energy storage material (Zinc air battery) [89]. A lab made zinc-air battery with a Zn plate as the anode was constructed by coupling the NiCoS/Ti3C2T x nanoarchitecture with Pt/C and loading this onto Ni foam to form a cathode; the device exhibited good stability, and the charge–discharge voltage gap (0.7 V) was lower than that of the noble-metal/air cathode [151]. Additionally, when applied as a cathode material (Ti3C2T x /Co–BDC + Pt/C) at a current density of 50 mV cm−2, the catalyst exhibited better charge–discharge performance than a standard IrO2 + Pt/C battery (Fig. 16 a–d). The catalyst was sufficiently stable and applied successfully to generate power, for example, to illuminate red-light-emitting diodes. The OER activity of the 2D Ti3C2T x /Co–BDC nanoarchitecture was discussed in the 4.2 electrocatalyst section. 4.1.2 Supercapacitors SCs with high power and rate performances and long cycle life also show promise as electrochemical-energy-storage devices because they can overcome the limitations of conventional capacitors and rechargeable batteries [152]. However, SCs have certain disadvantages such as low areal capacitance, low energy density, and poor cycling stability, which limit their widespread commercialization [153,154]. Nevertheless, MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures with high porosity, large surface area, abundant active sites, and tunable redox channels have garnered attention as superior electrode materials for SCs owing to the remarkable properties of MOFs and MXenes [155]. The intercalation of MOF precursors between MXene layers prevents the self-accumulation of MXene nanolayers, which effectively reduces the diffusion distance of the electrolyte and promotes electrolyte transport, resulting in high conductivity and a considerably enhanced pseudocapacitance of the MOF/MXene-based electrode material [156]. Diverse combinations of MOFs and MXenes have recently been reported for use in batteries and SCSs, with a view toward enhancing storage capacity and stability. These developments have yielded several design strategies with the potential for developing effective SCs. In 2022, Liu et al. [157] employed an adaptable approach to fabricate geometrical symmetric 3D MXene/MOF structures—Ti3C2T x /Cu-BTC, Ti3C2T x /FeCo-PBA, and Ti3C2T x /ZIF-67—via coprecipitation or in situ nucleation of the MOF in the presence of i3C2T x . The stability and conductivity of the composite were notably improved. Further, the Ti3C2T x /ZIF-67/CoV2O6 architecture exhibited noteworthy electrochemical performance (285.5F g−1). Electrostatic repulsion between the MXene sheets was observed to vanish, which further aided the nucleation of the MOF particles. In the MXene/MOF nanoarchitectures, the 3D space of the MOF particles was crucial for preventing aggregation of the MXene sheets and facilitating electrolyte transfer. The MXene layers increased the electrical conductivity and further enhanced the pseudo capacitance. Additionally, the Ti3C2T x /ZIF-67/CoV2O6 composites realized superior ion-conversion exchange, which helped compensate for the inferior conductivity of the MOF and further enhanced the electrolyte transfer. In another interesting study, a freestanding electrode based on the Co-MOF/Ti3C2T x /carbon nanofiber system was synthesized for SCs (Fig. 17 ) [94]. Using a highly conductive and flexible MX-CNF mat, an efficient and widely scalable manufacturing approach has been demonstrated for two types of electrodes—Co-PC@MX-CNF and MnO2@Co3O4-PC@MX-CNF. The two electrodes exhibited superior physicochemical characteristics and hierarchical porous architectures. Additionally, in a negative-potential window (ranging from −1 to 0 V), Co-PC@MXCNF exhibited a high capacitance (426.7 F g−1) at a current density of 1 A g−1. Moreover, the MnO2@Co3O4- PC@MX-CNF electrode material exhibited a gravimetric capacity of 475.4 mA h g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1 in the potential window 0–0.5 V. Owing to the two distinct characteristics of the electrodes, the fabricated device exhibited an ideal upper-limit working voltage (1.5 V), adequate energy density (72.5 W h kg−1) at a high power density (832.4 W kg−1), and capacitance retention of 90.36% after 10,000 repeated cycles. Furthermore, the designed structures exhibited outstanding mechanical stability and bendability without compromising their electrochemical performance. Yang et al. reported the temperature-controlled in situ growth of a Ni-MOFs/V2CT x composite, in which the Ni-MOF has chemically bound to the surface of V2CT x via Ni–O–V bridging bonds, which was anticipated to enhance the conductivity and reactivity of the composite [158]. During electrochemical analysis, the Ni-MOF/V2CT x /NF-300 architecture (optimized at 300 °C) exhibited an ultrahigh specific capacity (1103.9 C g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1). Furthermore, the Ni-MOF/V2CT x /NF-300/activated-carbon/NF device delivered a good energy density (46.3 W h kg−1) at a power density of 746.8 W kg−1 and exhibited exceptional cycling stability with a higher final capacity (118.1% of the initial value at the 15,000th cycle). A Ti3C2@pillar-layered Ni-MOF composite with high conductivity and cycling stability has also been reported [158]. In this structure, Ni–N bonds were responsible for the stability of the Ni- MOF nanopillars. Moreover, the MXene immobilized the Ni-MOF nanosheets, permitting rapid charge transfer between the two materials, which enhanced the inferior conductivity of the Ni-MOF and prevented aggregation of the pillar-type Ni-MOF nanosheets (Fig. 18 ). Furthermore, the stable connections between the organic ligands of the pillar-type Ni-MOF nanosheets and the surface terminal groups of Ti3C2 were crucial because they accelerated ion transport by lowering the oxygen reactivity of the surface groups and limiting the MXene oxidation. Consequently, the aqueous asymmetric Ti3C2@Ni-MOF-based SC showed an exceptional specific capacitance (979 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1) and operated up to 5000cycles with 2% capacitance degradation. Wang et al. prepared a Ti3C2T x -Ni-Co@NiCo-MOF/NF (M−NC@NCM/NF) composite via electrodeposition (see Fig. 19 a–c) for the synthesis pathway, morphology, and charge/discharge mechanism of the electrodeposited M−NC@NCM/NF composite) [159]. The nanosheets acquired a unique hexagonal shape owing to the distribution of Ni-MOF between the MXene layers. As an SC electrode material, the aforementioned composite delivered a high specific capacitance of 855.0 C g−1 (2137.5 F g−1) at a current density of 1 A g−1 after 5000cycles with a capacity retention of 75.3%. Zhang et al. prepared Ni-MOF microstrips using the MXene induction process [137] and observed the belt-shaped microstructure of the MXene containing oxygen functional groups on its surface (see Fig. 19d) for a schematic illustrating the agglomeration of Ni-MOF microstrips with and without Ti3C2T x ). Asymmetric SCs fabricated using the Ti3C2T x /Ni-MOF-based cathode in combination with active carbon (AC) anode exhibited 74.8% capacitance retention at the 4000th cycle at 10 A g−1. Recently, Ni/Co-MOF was integrated with an aminated MXene to produce highly stable SCs [95]. Essentially, an amination scheme was adopted for the MXene that coordinated with its surface functional groups to promote its hydrophilicity, and the Ni/Co-MOF was subsequently grown between the Ti3C2T x -NH2 sheets (Fig. 20 ). This method improved the effective accessible electrolytic interfacial area of the electrode and established a stable conductive framework as an adequate foundation for in situ growth of the MOF. Devices fabricated using Ni/Co-MOF@ Ti3C2T x -NH2/AC exhibited high-rate stability until 15,600 cycles, with a high energy density of 98.1 W h kg−1 at a power density of 600 W kg−1. Wang et al. recently fabricated 2D//2D NiCo-MOF/Ti3C2T x using a simple ultrasonic method [159]. The NiCo-MOF/Ti3C2T x heterostructures exhibited exceptional electrochemical characteristics owing to the high conductivity of the MXene, the enhanced redox sites of the ultrathin 2D NiCo-MOF nanosheets, and short charge-transfer pathways. Consequently, the ideal NiCo-MOF/M10 electrode exhibited a considerably higher capacitance (1176.8 F g−1 at 1 A g−1) and longer cycle life (10,000 cycles) than those of pure NiCo-MOF. Additionally, the NiCo-MOF/M10 used as the cathode in a two-electrode configuration exhibited exceptional energy storage capability. A MOF has been derived dendrite-like CoNi2S4/MXene architecture using a two-step solvothermal strategy [156]. Briefly, ZIF-67 nanoflakes were formed on Ni foam, and the morphology of the nanoflakes was changed to a dendritic architecture upon treatment with an MXene and thioacetamide, as the nanoflakes exhibited fragmented structures and formed small nanoparticles that were converted to nanorods. Moreover, the external nanoparticles expanded into branches that were then coated by the MXenes, and the internal nanoparticles transformed into trunks. This dendritic architecture provided large active sites that formed pathways suitable for electron conduction and ion transport, resulting in an exceptional specific capacitance of 900Cg−1 and a remarkable rate performance. Overall, these design-related developments can be leveraged to develop effective SCs. The enhanced electrochemical performance of various MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures employed as integral parts of batteries and SCs are summarized in Table S2 [92–160]. Overall, the comprehensive discussion of various novel approaches presented herein highlights the viability of MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures in remedying the existing issues of batteries and SCs. Specifically, the conductivity of the electrode material can be maintained without compromising porosity, which can enhance the ion intercalation thereafter storage capacity. While MXenes primarily assist in maintaining the electric conductivity, MOFs actively mitigate the volume expansion during ion absorption/desorption and act as excellent cages for trapping shuttling species and inhibit dendrite growth, owing to their symmetric porosity between the MXene nanosheets. Interlayer coordination bonds (–O– and –N=) are established between the MXene and MOF, which effectively preserve the stability and prolong the lifespan of energy storage devices. In addition to the advantages, the inadequate redox sites of MXenes and the low electrical conductivity of MOFs are compensated via mutual coordination in the hybrid heterostructure. 4.2 Electrochemical energy conversion (HER, OER, and ORR) The development of high-quality catalysts with sufficient conversion performance is remarkably challenging. In particular, catalyst related issues like agglomeration, scarcity of active sites, and poor stability result in sluggish kinetics for energy conversion reactions such as H2 fuel production, a crucial process. Therefore, the realization of highly active sites, high specific surface areas, and porous durable channels are critical. Currently, MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures are a trailblazing material for electrochemical catalysis [95,119,120]. The strong electrostatic and chemical linkages between the intercalated MOF precursor within the MXene layers generate abundant catalytic active sites, ion channels (H+ or OH−), and extremely rapid charge transfer, leading to an enhanced electrical conductivity, prevention of the aggregation, obliteration of the MOF precursor, and a concurrent increase in the mechanical durability of the catalyst during catalytic processes like the ORR, HER, OER, and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) [161]. 4.2.1 Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) MOF/MXene catalysts have been prepared for the OER, which is a crucial step in fuel conversion processes. For instance, in-situ growth of a bimetallic MOF on an MXene has been achieved via coprecipitation. The presence of numerous surface terminations on the MXene triggered the in situ growth of ZIF-67, and the active sites of Co and Ni were intercalated into the highly conductive 2D layered Ti3C2T x , leading to an excellent OER activity with a lower onset potential and Tafel slope than those of IrO2 and bare MOF catalysts [162]. In addition to MOF derived Ni and Co, the S heteroatoms have also been introduced to the MXene sheets. The abundant negatively charged surface functional groups (zeta potential = −19.9 mV) distributed on Ti3C2T x adsorbed Co2+ ions via electrostatic interactions, coordinated with 2-methylimdazole, and then nucleated, thereby producing the ZIF-67/Ti3C2T x nanoarchitecture. The product was further treated with the Ni moiety, and Co2+/Co3+ ions were coprecipitated with the Ni2+ ions, with sulphuration yielding the NiCoS/Ti3C2T x nanoarchitecture. During the OER, this nanoarchitecture underwent an irreversible chemical structural transformation, yielding oxides and hydroxides; exhibited intrinsic catalytic activity; and triggered water oxidation, in contrast to bare NiCo-LDH and NiCoS. MOF-derived Co-Fe layered double hydroxides (MLDHs) have been intercalated with multifunctional layered Ti3C2 via coprecipitation. Compared to commercial RuO2, Co-Fe MLDH@Ti3C2 exhibited a remarkably low overpotential and achieved values of only 170 and 238 mV at current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2 [93]. Ti3C2T x /Co–BDC nanoarchitectures have been employed as an OER catalyst (Fig. 21 ) [95]. The catalyst exhibited an excellent potential of 1.60 V vs. RHE and a Tafel slope of 48.2 mVdec−1 with a glassy carbon electrode in an alkaline medium; these values were higher than those of transition-metal-based catalysts. 4.2.2 Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) The ORR plays a vital role in clean energy systems, particularly in fuel cells. Commercial Pt/C catalysts exhibit optimal ORR activity; however, their high cost and low availability impede their widespread adoption. Additionally, the development of catalyst alternatives to Pt/C using earth-abundant materials with high catalytic activity and stability is challenging. Nevertheless, MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures with numerous active sites, high porosity, and decent stability can be viable as ORR catalyst materials. For instance, a MOF-derived Fe-N-C-incorporated Ti3C2T x nanoarchitecture was successfully synthesized by pyrolysis and applied as an ORR catalyst. The Fe-N-C@Ti3C2T x nanoarchitecture achieved excellent ORR activity with a half-wave potential of 0.887 V vs. RHE, a limiting diffusion current of 6.3 mA cm−2, and high stability even after 10,000 cycles in an alkaline medium. A similar ORR performance was observed in an acidic medium, indicating that the presence of strong coupling interactions between the MOF-derived Fe-N-C and MXene, the increased electrochemically active surface area, and reduced intrinsic and charge-transfer impendence triggered the ORR activity [163]. 4.2.3 Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) Hydrogen fuel is an advanced renewable energy source that can reduce fossil fuel dependence because of its high energy capacity and low carbon emissions. A Ti3C2T x @MOF-CoP nanoarchitecture, which was remarkably less expensive than Pt/C, was generated by subjecting a ZIF67-derived Co-embedded MOF to phosphating [161]. Interestingly, the Ti3C2T x @MOF-CoP nanoarchitecture exhibited HER activity in various electrolytes (1 M KOH, 1 M PBS, and 0.5 M H2SO4) over a wide pH range. Additionally, the nanoarchitecture-based catalyst exhibited OER activity in an alkaline medium. Furthermore, the Ti3C2T x @MOF-CoP nanoarchitecture was applied as a bifunctional catalyst for overall water splitting, leading to a lower bias voltage (1.61 V) than that of MOF-Co-P. The results collectively indicate that MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures can chart a new path for creating highly active sites and ensuring stability to achieve low-cost hydrogen production via overall electrochemical water splitting. Ma et al. developed MIL-100 (Fe)/Ti3C2N x 2D nanoarchitecture by in situ solvothermal method and applied it as an electrocatalyst for HER as shown in (Fig. 22 ) [164]. The MIL/Ti3C2N x showed high HER activity with a low overpotential of 107 mV, and remarkable stability at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, which is superior to those of pristine MIL-100(Fe) and Ti3C2N x catalysts. The intercalation of MOF nanocrystals in between the MXene layers can create high surface area, and abundant pore channels, preventing restacking, which leads to splendid electrical conductivity as well exposure to high catalytic active sites during the electrocatalysis process. An oxygen vacancy defect site has Ce-MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture synthesized by in situ hydrothermal method by Li et al. [165]. The MXene surface hydroxyl group attracts the cerium ions and initiates the in-situ growth of MOF having oxygen vacancies defect sites. Interestingly, the developed defect site shave Ce-MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture exhibits multiple electrochemical applications (OER, HER, and supercapacitor) energy storage and conversion as shown in (Fig. 23 ). The catalyst exhibits OER, and HER activity with overpotential as low as 270 and 220 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2, which is higher than pristine MOF and MXene. In addition, the Ce-MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture showed a specific capacity of 496 F g−1, which is better than that of pristine MOF and MXene. The porous, defective sites have MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture design that is highly desired for energy storage and conversion applications. 5 Concluding remarks and future perspectives As a new class of innovative emerging materials, specially designed MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures with exceptional properties have been spotlighted in various research areas, such as chemical sciences, catalysis, material science, physics, nanotechnology, and environmental engineering. In this review, the various synthesis strategies have been detailed for MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures with different morphologies and their electrochemical energy-storage-and-conversion characteristics. By tailoring the synthesis conditions, 0D, 1D, 2D, and 3D MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures with the following interesting features are developed: 1. Ultralow weight 2. Chemical and thermal durability 3. Abundant active-edge sites 4. Tunable porosity 5. Redox-active sites 6. Considerable storage capacity 7. Economic benefits 8. High conductivity Challenges and perspectives. To date, most studies have focused on the architectures of MOFs with different MXenes; however, the development of diverse MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures with different MXenes should be prioritized. (i) The main obstacle to developing MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures for electrochemical energy storage and conversion is the lack of clear insights into reaction mechanisms. As per the literature, no specific theoretical studies have been conducted to acquire these insights. Therefore, theoretical investigations in this context must be encouraged as they can lead to applications in chemical, physical, nano, and engineering technologies. (ii) MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures should be receptive to tuning in terms of pH, as benign catalysts typically perform electrochemical energy conversion over the entire pH range (0–14); this can also resolve economic issues. Because reducing the usage of chemicals, and equipment does not need to design new nanoarchitectures, which are having pH limitations. (iii) Additionally, the types of defects in MOF/MXene heterostructures have not been comprehensively unveiled owing to the complexity of the nanoarchitectures; therefore, efforts must be devoted to identifying the defects, which would provide a clear path for developing effective MOF/MXene-based electrochemical catalysts. (iv) The MOF/MXene design strategies should be further explored because they are in their infancy. Over 20,000 MOFs have been reported, therefore in the future, the development of these MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures is highly desired. For instance, new MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures could be designed using different economically viable techniques such as microwave-assisted procedures, sol–gel methods, and chemical vapor deposition with the thousands of MOFs that have been developed to date. (v) Controlling the size of MOF particles and surface functional groups of MXene is a key aspect to avoid the aggregation and enhance the quality of the MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures. Intercalation of MOF-derived single atoms between the MXene layers provides effective active sites with porous channels and allows rapid ion diffusion in the presence of an electrolyte, which results in a high activity of the MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture catalysts. (vi) Furthermore, membranes, ultrasmall nanoclusters, hydrogels, conductive inks, thin films, micromotors, and wearable devices can be prepared using MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures. Moreover, using MXene precursor design covalent organic frame/MXene nanoarchitecture is another interesting strategy to expand these MOF, MXene-related nanoarchitectures. Additionally, some factors should be considered for the commercialization of this MOF/MXene nanoarchitecture (Fig. 24 ). (vii) For commercialization and industrialization, the selectivity of the starting materials should be cost-effective, and the stability and reliability of nanoarchitectures in broad conditions like pH, temperature, and air sensitivity. Therefore, selecting abundantly available non-noble metal (Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Al, etc.,) precursors is highly desired to make economically viable MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures. (viii) Chemical bioengineering is another field with potential application for MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures, as it urgently requires biocompatible, flexible, and bioelectronic energy-storage capacitor implants. Hope, the above details will inspire most readers from chemistry, chemical engineering, physics, materials science, and bioelectronics to push this field a step further to design various porous MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures and their applications in the energy sector. coredata.dc:description: The development of urbanization and industrialization leads to rapid depletion of fossil fuels. Therefore, the production of fuel from renewable resources is highly desired. Electrotechnical energy conversion and storage is a benign technique with reliable output and is eco-friendly. Developing an exceptional electrochemical catalyst with tunable properties like a huge specific surface area, porous channels, and abundant active sites is critical points. Recently, Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and two-dimensional (2D) transition-metal carbides/nitrides (MXenes) have been extensively investigated in the field of electrochemical energy conversion and storage. However, advances in the research on MOFs are hampered by their limited structural stability and conventionally low electrical conductivity, whereas the practical electrochemical performance of MXenes is impeded by their low porosity, inadequate redox sites, and agglomeration. Consequently, researchers have been designing MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures to overcome the limitations in electrochemical energy conversion and storage. This review explores the recent advances in MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures design strategies, tailoring their properties based on the morphologies (0D, 1D, 2D, and 3D), and broadening their future opportunities in electrochemical energy storage (batteries, supercapacitors) and catalytic energy conversion (HER, OER, and ORR). The intercalation of MOF in between the MXene layers in the nanoarchitectures functions synergistically to address the issues associated with bare MXene and MOF in the electrochemical energy storage and conversion. This review gives a clear emphasis on the general aspects of MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures, and the future research perspectives, challenges of MOF/MXene design strategies and electrochemical applications are highlighted.
